author: ajsutton
content: Geth probably needs to be given the same `--jwt-secret` .  If you're pointing at the file that geth created, there's a bit of a catch that the spec says it should be overwritten on each start up, so if you start geth after lighthouse they'll wind up with different secrets even if they're pointing to the same file.

content: Besu does and has an issue in progress on the subject: https://github.com/hyperledger/besu/issues/3966

author: m.kalinin
content: LVH stands for `latestValidHash` parameter and is a part of `PayloadStatus` response, used when `status: INVALID` to point to the most recent *valid* ancestor of the chain the given payload does belong to. Say `P1 <- INV_P2 <- P3`, `INV_P2` induced `SYNCING` as `P1` is missing, then a node pulls `P1` from the network and it appears that `INV_P2` is `INVALID`. CL is expecting `status: INVALID, latestValidHash: P1.blockHash` in the response to `newPayload(P3)`

author: tersec
content:
Attempting to use `eth_chainId` with Geth, but despite saying:
> WARN [06-21|18:33:37.253] Local chain is post-merge, waiting for beacon client sync switch-over... 

after having run for a while without any CL involved, it still states:
> > eth.chainId()
> Error: chain not synced beyond EIP-155 replay-protection fork block
>         at web3.js:6365:9(45)
>         at send (web3.js:5099:62(34))
>         at <eval>:1:12(3)

This is kind of a blocking issue. If it's just `getBlockByNumber('latest')` being the genesis block (which it is) for some reason, well, alright, maybe that's cosmetic. But a CL needs to be able to verify the chain is correct.  It behaves a little oddly in how it returns the answer, but it does return an answer:
> > net.version()
> TypeError: Value is not an object: 3
>         at <eval>:1:12(3)

so until Geth can return `eth_chainId` meaningfully in the most ideal situation I've managed to set up with it, then it's a regression I'm not sure I'm willing to make in Nimbus to change from `net_version` to `eth_chainId`
